Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Lobar and Sublobar Resection in Peripheral cT1aN0 NSCLC

Background: This study evaluates differences in disease-free survival (DFS), overall survival (OS), and lung cancer-specific survival (LCSS) between lobar resection (LR), segmental resection (SR), and wedge resection (WR) in patients with peripheral cT1aN0 NSCLC.

Methods: In this randomised controlled trial, 697 patients were enrolled between June 2007 and March 2017. Participants were randomised to LR (357) or sublobar resection (SLR) (340), stratified by clinical tumor size, histology, and smoking history. Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment. The primary outcome was DFS over five years. Blinding was not applied.

Results: A total of 362 patients underwent LR, 131 SR, and 204 WR. Five-year DFS was 64.7% for LR, 63.8% for SR, and 62.5% for WR (p = 0.888). Five-year OS was 78.7% for LR, 81.9% for SR, and 79.7% for WR (p = 0.873). Five-year LCSS was 86.8% for LR, 89.2% for SR, and 89.7% for WR (p = 0.903). Locoregional recurrence occurred in 12% of SR and 14% of WR (p = 0.295). Median reduction in % FEV1 at 6 months was 5% for WR and 3% for SR (p = 0.930).

Interpretation: LR, SR, and WR showed similar survival outcomes. No significant differences were observed in locoregional recurrence or FEV1 reduction between SR and WR.
